trans-unit.source: Subclassing a numpy.ndarray is possible but if your goal is to create an array with modified behavior, as do dask arrays for distributed computation and cupy arrays for GPU-based computation, subclassing is discouraged. Instead, using numpy’s dispatch mechanism is recommended.

trans-unit.source: Suppose x.shape is (10,20,30) and ind is a (2,3,4)-shaped indexing intp array, then result = x[...,ind,:] has shape (10,2,3,4,30) because the (20,)-shaped subspace has been replaced with a (2,3,4)-shaped broadcasted indexing subspace. If we let i, j, k loop over the (2,3,4)-shaped subspace then result[...,i,j,k,:] = x[...,ind[i,j,k],:]. This example produces the same result as x.take(ind, axis=-2).
trans-unit.target: Suponga que x.shape es (10,20,30) e ind es una matriz intp de indexación con forma (2,3,4) , entonces result = x[...,ind,:] tiene forma (10,2,3 , 4,30) porque el subespacio con forma de (20,) ha sido reemplazado por un subespacio de indexación transmitido con forma de (2,3,4). Si dejamos que i, j, k recorra el subespacio en forma de (2,3,4), el result[...,i,j,k,:] = x[...,ind[i,j,k],:] . Este ejemplo produce el mismo resultado que x.take(ind, axis=-2) .

trans-unit.source: Suppose that the commit history looks like this:

Suppose the first operand is one dimensional and the second operand is two dimensional. The iterator will have three dimensions, so op_axes will have two 3-element lists. The first list picks out the one axis of the first operand, and is -1 for the rest of the iterator axes, with a final result of [0, -1, -1]. The second list picks out the two axes of the second operand, but shouldn’t overlap with the axes picked out in the first operand. Its list is [-1, 0, 1]. The output operand maps onto the iterator axes in the standard manner, so we can provide None instead of constructing another list.
trans-unit.target: Suponga que el primer operando es unidimensional y el segundo operando es bidimensional. El iterador tendrá tres dimensiones, por lo que op_axes tendrá dos listas de 3 elementos. La primera lista selecciona un eje del primer operando y es -1 para el resto de los ejes del iterador, con un resultado final de [0, -1, -1]. La segunda lista selecciona los dos ejes del segundo operando, pero no debe superponerse con los ejes seleccionados en el primer operando. Su lista es [-1, 0, 1]. El operando de salida se asigna a los ejes del iterador de la manera estándar, por lo que podemos proporcionar Ninguno en lugar de construir otra lista.

THE RESULTING LOGIT FUNCTION IS NOT FAST! numpy.vectorize simply loops over spam.logit. The loop is done at the C level, but the numpy array is constantly being parsed and build back up. This is expensive. When the author compared numpy.vectorize(spam.logit) against the logit ufuncs constructed below, the logit ufuncs were almost exactly 4 times faster. Larger or smaller speedups are, of course, possible depending on the nature of the function.

Tests on random data
trans-unit.target: Pruebas con datos aleatorios

trans-unit.source: Tests on random data are good, but since test failures are meant to expose new bugs or regressions, a test that passes most of the time but fails occasionally with no code changes is not helpful. Make the random data deterministic by setting the random number seed before generating it. Use either Python’s random.seed(some_number) or NumPy’s numpy.random.seed(some_number), depending on the source of random numbers.
trans-unit.target: Las pruebas con datos aleatorios son buenas, pero dado que las fallas de las pruebas están destinadas a exponer nuevos errores o regresiones, una prueba que pasa la mayor parte del tiempo pero falla ocasionalmente sin cambios de código no es útil. Haga que los datos aleatorios sean deterministas estableciendo la semilla del número aleatorio antes de generarlos. Utilice la random.seed(some_number) Python (algún_number) o la numpy.random.seed(some_number) de NumPy (algún_number) , según la fuente de los números aleatorios.

trans-unit.source: The PyArrayDescr_Type is the built-in type of the data-type-descriptor objects used to describe how the bytes comprising the array are to be interpreted. There are 21 statically-defined PyArray_Descr objects for the built-in data-types. While these participate in reference counting, their reference count should never reach zero. There is also a dynamic table of user-defined PyArray_Descr objects that is also maintained. Once a data-type-descriptor object is “registered” it should never be deallocated either. The function PyArray_DescrFromType (…) can be used to retrieve a PyArray_Descr object from an enumerated type-number (either built-in or user- defined).

The PyArrayDescr_Type is the built-in type of the data-type-descriptor objects used to describe how the bytes comprising the array are to be interpreted. There are 21 statically-defined PyArray_Descr objects for the built-in data-types. While these participate in reference counting, their reference count should never reach zero. There is also a dynamic table of user-defined PyArray_Descr objects that is also maintained. Once a data-type-descriptor object is “registered” it should never be deallocated either. The function PyArray_DescrFromType (…) can be used to retrieve a PyArray_Descr object from an enumerated type-number (either built-in or user- defined).
trans-unit.target: El PyArrayDescr_Type es la incorporada en el tipo de los datos de tipo-descriptor objetos utilizados para describir cómo los bytes que comprenden la matriz han de interpretarse. Hay 21 objetos PyArray_Descr definidos estáticamente para los tipos de datos integrados. Si bien estos participan en el recuento de referencias, su recuento de referencias nunca debe llegar a cero. También hay una tabla dinámica de objetos PyArray_Descr definidos por el usuario que también se mantiene. Una vez que un objeto descriptor de tipo de datos está “registrado”, tampoco debe desasignarse nunca. La función PyArray_DescrFromType (…) se puede utilizar para recuperar un objeto PyArray_Descr de un número de tipo enumerado (ya sea integrado o definido por el usuario).

trans-unit.source: The PyArrayInterface structure is defined so that NumPy and other extension modules can use the rapid array interface protocol. The __array_struct__ method of an object that supports the rapid array interface protocol should return a PyCObject that contains a pointer to a PyArrayInterface structure with the relevant details of the array. After the new array is created, the attribute should be DECREF’d which will free the PyArrayInterface structure. Remember to INCREF the object (whose __array_struct__ attribute was retrieved) and point the base member of the new PyArrayObject to this same object. In this way the memory for the array will be managed correctly.
trans-unit.target: La estructura PyArrayInterface está definida para que NumPy y otros módulos de extensión puedan usar el protocolo de interfaz de matriz rápida. El método __array_struct__ de un objeto que admite el protocolo de interfaz de matriz rápida debe devolver un PyCObject que contenga un puntero a una estructura PyArrayInterface con los detalles relevantes de la matriz. Después de que se crea la nueva matriz, el atributo debe ser DECREF 'd que liberará la estructura PyArrayInterface . Recuerde INCREF el objeto (cuyo atributo __array_struct__ fue recuperado) y apunte el miembro base del nuevo PyArrayObject a este mismo objeto. De esta forma, la memoria de la matriz se gestionará correctamente.

trans-unit.source: The PyArrayObject C-structure contains all of the required information for an array. All instances of an ndarray (and its subclasses) will have this structure. For future compatibility, these structure members should normally be accessed using the provided macros. If you need a shorter name, then you can make use of NPY_AO (deprecated) which is defined to be equivalent to PyArrayObject.

Para compatibilidad futura, normalmente se debe acceder a estos miembros de estructura utilizando las macros proporcionadas. Si necesita un nombre más corto, puede utilizar NPY_AO (obsoleto), que se define como equivalente a PyArrayObject .

trans-unit.source: The PyArrayObject C-structure contains all of the required information for an array. All instances of an ndarray (and its subclasses) will have this structure. For future compatibility, these structure members should normally be accessed using the provided macros. If you need a shorter name, then you can make use of NPY_AO (deprecated) which is defined to be equivalent to PyArrayObject. Direct access to the struct fields are deprecated. Use the PyArray_*(arr) form instead.

trans-unit.source: The Generator provides access to a wide range of distributions, and served as a replacement for RandomState. The main difference between the two is that Generator relies on an additional BitGenerator to manage state and generate the random bits, which are then transformed into random values from useful distributions. The default BitGenerator used by Generator is PCG64. The BitGenerator can be changed by passing an instantized BitGenerator to Generator.

The Generator provides access to a wide range of distributions, and served as a replacement for RandomState. The main difference between the two is that Generator relies on an additional BitGenerator to manage state and generate the random bits, which are then transformed into random values from useful distributions. The default BitGenerator used by Generator is PCG64. The BitGenerator can be changed by passing an instantized BitGenerator to Generator.
trans-unit.target: El Generator proporciona acceso a una amplia gama de distribuciones y sirvió como reemplazo de RandomState . La principal diferencia entre los dos es que Generator se basa en un BitGenerator adicional para administrar el estado y generar los bits aleatorios, que luego se transforman en valores aleatorios a partir de distribuciones útiles. El BitGenerator predeterminado utilizado por Generator es PCG64 . El BitGenerator se puede cambiar pasando un BitGenerator instanciado a Generator .

trans-unit.source: The RandomState provides access to legacy generators. This generator is considered frozen and will have no further improvements. It is guaranteed to produce the same values as the final point release of NumPy v1.16. These all depend on Box-Muller normals or inverse CDF exponentials or gammas. This class should only be used if it is essential to have randoms that are identical to what would have been produced by previous versions of NumPy.

This class should only be used if it is essential to have randoms that are identical to what would have been produced by previous versions of NumPy.
trans-unit.target: El RandomState proporciona acceso a los generadores de legado. Este generador se considera congelado y no tendrá más mejoras. Se garantiza que producirá los mismos valores que la versión final de NumPy v1.16. Todos estos dependen de las normales de Box-Muller o de las exponenciales CDF inversas o gammas. Esta clase solo debe usarse si es esencial tener randoms que sean idénticos a los que habrían sido producidos por versiones anteriores de NumPy.

The PyArray_Broadcast function takes the iterators that have already been defined and uses them to determine the broadcast shape in each dimension (to create the iterators at the same time that broadcasting occurs then use the PyMultiIter_New function). Then, the iterators are adjusted so that each iterator thinks it is iterating over an array with the broadcast size. This is done by adjusting the iterators number of dimensions, and the shape in each dimension. This works because the iterator strides are also adjusted. Broadcasting only adjusts (or adds) length-1 dimensions. For these dimensions, the strides variable is simply set to 0 so that the data-pointer for the iterator over that array doesn’t move as the broadcasting operation operates over the extended dimension.
trans-unit.target: La función PyArray_Broadcast toma los iteradores que ya se han definido y los usa para determinar la forma de transmisión en cada dimensión (para crear los iteradores al mismo tiempo que ocurre la transmisión, use la función PyMultiIter_New ). Luego, los iteradores se ajustan para que cada iterador piense que está iterando sobre una matriz con el tamaño de transmisión. Esto se hace ajustando el número de dimensiones de los iteradores y la forma en cada dimensión. Esto funciona porque los pasos del iterador también se ajustan. La transmisión solo ajusta (o agrega) dimensiones de longitud 1. Para estas dimensiones, la variable de pasos simplemente se establece en 0 para que el puntero de datos para el iterador sobre esa matriz no se mueva mientras la operación de transmisión opera en la dimensión extendida.

trans-unit.source: The PyArray_Broadcast function takes the iterators that have already been defined and uses them to determine the broadcast shape in each dimension (to create the iterators at the same time that broadcasting occurs then use the PyMultiIter_New function). Then, the iterators are adjusted so that each iterator thinks it is iterating over an array with the broadcast size. This is done by adjusting the iterators number of dimensions, and the shape in each dimension. This works because the iterator strides are also adjusted. Broadcasting only adjusts (or adds) length-1 dimensions. For these dimensions, the strides variable is simply set to 0 so that the data-pointer for the iterator over that array doesn’t move as the broadcasting operation operates over the extended dimension.

trans-unit.source: The ndarray can be inherited from (in Python or in C) if desired. Therefore, it can form a foundation for many useful classes. Often whether to sub-class the array object or to simply use the core array component as an internal part of a new class is a difficult decision, and can be simply a matter of choice. NumPy has several tools for simplifying how your new object interacts with other array objects, and so the choice may not be significant in the end. One way to simplify the question is by asking yourself if the object you are interested in can be replaced as a single array or does it really require two or more arrays at its core.
trans-unit.target: El ndarray se puede heredar (en Python o en C) si se desea. Por lo tanto, puede formar la base de muchas clases útiles. A menudo, si subclasificar el objeto de matriz o simplemente usar el componente de matriz principal como parte interna de una nueva clase es una decisión difícil y puede ser simplemente una cuestión de elección. NumPy tiene varias herramientas para simplificar la forma en que su nuevo objeto interactúa con otros objetos de matriz, por lo que la elección puede no ser significativa al final. Una forma de simplificar la pregunta es preguntándose si el objeto que le interesa se puede reemplazar como una sola matriz o si realmente requiere dos o más matrices en su núcleo.

trans-unit.source: The nditer will try to provide chunks that are as large as possible to the inner loop. By forcing ‘C’ and ‘F’ order, we get different external loop sizes. This mode is enabled by specifying an iterator flag.

The SWIG type checking and conversion system is a complicated combination of C macros, SWIG macros, SWIG typemaps and SWIG fragments. Fragments are a way to conditionally insert code into your wrapper file if it is needed, and not insert it if not needed. If multiple typemaps require the same fragment, the fragment only gets inserted into your wrapper code once.
trans-unit.target: El SWIG sistema de comprobación de tipos y la conversión es una combinación complicada de macros C, SWIG macros, SWIG typemaps y SWIG fragmentos. Los fragmentos son una forma de insertar código condicionalmente en su archivo contenedor si es necesario, y no insertarlo si no es necesario. Si varios mapas de tipos requieren el mismo fragmento, el fragmento solo se inserta en su código contenedor una vez.

The -s flag makes a PGP (usually GPG) signed tag. Please do sign the release tags.

The -v flag gives verbose feedback, -s causes the script to sign the wheels with your GPG key before upload. Don’t forget to upload the wheels before the source tarball, so there is no period for which people switch from an expected binary install to a source install from PyPI.

The .npy format is the standard binary file format in NumPy for persisting a single arbitrary NumPy array on disk. The format stores all of the shape and dtype information necessary to reconstruct the array correctly even on another machine with a different architecture. The format is designed to be as simple as possible while achieving its limited goals.
trans-unit.target: El formato .npy es el formato de archivo binario estándar en NumPy para conservar una única matriz NumPy arbitraria en el disco. El formato almacena toda la información de forma y tipo d necesaria para reconstruir la matriz correctamente incluso en otra máquina con una arquitectura diferente. El formato está diseñado para ser lo más simple posible mientras logra sus objetivos limitados.

trans-unit.source: The .npy format, including motivation for creating it and a comparison of alternatives, is described in the “npy-format” NEP, however details have evolved with time and this document is more current.
trans-unit.target: El formato .npy , incluida la motivación para crearlo y una comparación de alternativas, se describe en el NEP “formato npy” , sin embargo, los detalles han evolucionado con el tiempo y este documento es más actual.

trans-unit.source: The .npz file format is a zipped archive of files named after the variables they contain. The archive is compressed with zipfile.ZIP_DEFLATED and each file in the archive contains one variable in .npy format. For a description of the .npy format, see numpy.lib.format.
trans-unit.target: El formato de archivo .npz es un archivo comprimido de archivos con el nombre de las variables que contienen. El archivo está comprimido con zipfile.ZIP_DEFLATED y cada archivo del archivo contiene una variable en formato .npy . Para obtener una descripción del formato .npy , consulte numpy.lib.format .

trans-unit.source: The .npz file format is a zipped archive of files named after the variables they contain. The archive is not compressed and each file in the archive contains one variable in .npy format. For a description of the .npy format, see numpy.lib.format.
trans-unit.target: El formato de archivo .npz es un archivo comprimido de archivos con el nombre de las variables que contienen. El archivo no está comprimido y cada archivo del archivo contiene una variable en formato .npy . Para obtener una descripción del formato .npy , consulte numpy.lib.format .

trans-unit.source: The .npz format is the standard format for persisting multiple NumPy arrays on disk. A .npz file is a zip file containing multiple .npy files, one for each array.
trans-unit.target: El formato .npz es el formato estándar para conservar varias matrices NumPy en el disco. Un archivo .npz es un archivo zip que contiene varios archivos .npy , uno para cada matriz.

trans-unit.source: The ALIGNED flag of an ndarray, computed in IsAligned and checked by PyArray_ISALIGNED. This is computed from dtype.alignment. It is set to True if every item in the array is at a memory location consistent with dtype.alignment, which is the case if the data ptr and all strides of the array are multiples of that alignment.
trans-unit.target: El ALIGNED pabellón de un ndarray, calculada en IsAligned y verificado por PyArray_ISALIGNED . Esto se calcula a partir de dtype.alignment . Se establece en True si todos los elementos de la matriz están en una ubicación de memoria consistente con dtype.alignment , que es el caso si los datos ptr y todos los pasos de la matriz son múltiplos de esa alineación.

The PCG64 state vector consists of 2 unsigned 128-bit values, which are represented externally as Python ints. One is the state of the PRNG, which is advanced by a linear congruential generator (LCG). The second is a fixed odd increment used in the LCG.
trans-unit.target: El vector de estado PCG64 consta de 2 valores de 128 bits sin firmar, que se representan externamente como entradas de Python. Uno es el estado del PRNG, que es avanzado por un generador congruencial lineal (LCG). El segundo es un incremento impar fijo utilizado en la LCG.

trans-unit.source: The Philox state vector consists of a 256-bit value encoded as a 4-element uint64 array and a 128-bit value encoded as a 2-element uint64 array. The former is a counter which is incremented by 1 for every 4 64-bit randoms produced. The second is a key which determined the sequence produced. Using different keys produces independent sequences.
trans-unit.target: El vector de estado Philox consta de un valor de 256 bits codificado como una matriz uint64 de 4 elementos y un valor de 128 bits codificado como una matriz uint64 de 2 elementos. El primero es un contador que se incrementa en 1 por cada 4 randoms de 64 bits producidos. La segunda es una clave que determina la secuencia producida. El uso de diferentes claves produce secuencias independientes.

trans-unit.source: The SFC64 state vector consists of 4 unsigned 64-bit values. The last is a 64-bit counter that increments by 1 each iteration.
trans-unit.target: El vector de estado SFC64 consta de 4 valores de 64 bits sin signo. El último es un contador de 64 bits que se incrementa en 1 cada iteración.

trans-unit.source: The align keyword of the dtype constructor, which only affects structured arrays. If the structure’s field offsets are not manually provided numpy determines offsets automatically. In that case, align=True pads the structure so that each field is “true” aligned in memory and sets dtype.alignment to be the largest of the field “true” alignments. This is like what C-structs usually do. Otherwise if offsets or itemsize were manually provided align=True simply checks that all the fields are “true” aligned and that the total itemsize is a multiple of the largest field alignment. In either case dtype.isalignedstruct is also set to True.
trans-unit.target: La palabra clave align del constructor dtype, que solo afecta a las matrices estructuradas. Si las compensaciones de campo de la estructura no se proporcionan manualmente, numpy determina las compensaciones automáticamente. En ese caso, align=True rellena la estructura de modo que cada campo esté alineado "verdadero" en la memoria y establece dtype.alignment para que sea el mayor de los alineamientos "verdaderos" del campo. Esto es como lo que suelen hacer las estructuras C. De lo contrario, si las compensaciones o el tamaño del elemento se proporcionaron manualmente, align=True simplemente verifica que todos los campos estén alineados en "verdadero" y que el tamaño total del elemento sea un múltiplo de la alineación del campo más grande. En cualquier caso, dtype.isalignedstruct también se establece en True.

The Documentation for a software project is the set of reference, instructional, educational, informative material generated by the project developers and contributors, as well as discussions, presentations, videos and other user-generated content. It may include learning-oriented content (such as tutorials and how-tos), use-cases or in-depth explanations and reference for developers.

The bounds argument is expected to be a (2 * iter->ao->nd) arrays, such as the range bound[2*i]->bounds[2*i+1] defines the range where to walk for dimension i (both bounds are included in the walked coordinates). The bounds should be ordered for each dimension (bounds[2*i] <= bounds[2*i+1]).
trans-unit.target: Se espera que el argumento de límites sea ​​una matriz (2 * iter-> ao-> nd), como el rango límite [2 * i] -> límites [2 * i + 1] define el rango por donde caminar para la dimensión i (ambos límites están incluidos en las coordenadas caminadas). The API exposed by NumPy for third-party extensions has grown over years of releases, and has allowed programmers to directly access NumPy functionality from C. This API can be best described as “organic”. It has emerged from multiple competing desires and from multiple points of view over the years, strongly influenced by the desire to make it easy for users to move to NumPy from Numeric and Numarray. The core API originated with Numeric in 1995 and there are patterns such as the heavy use of macros written to mimic Python’s C-API as well as account for compiler technology of the late 90’s. There is also only a small group of volunteers who have had very little time to spend on improving this API.
trans-unit.target: La API expuesta por NumPy para extensiones de terceros ha crecido durante años de lanzamientos y ha permitido a los programadores acceder directamente a la funcionalidad de NumPy desde C. Esta API puede describirse mejor como "orgánica". Ha surgido de múltiples deseos en competencia y de múltiples puntos de vista a lo largo de los años, fuertemente influenciado por el deseo de facilitar a los usuarios el cambio a NumPy desde Numeric y Numarray. La API central se originó con Numeric en 1995 y existen patrones como el uso intensivo de macros escritas para imitar la C-API de Python, así como para tener en cuenta la tecnología de compilación de finales de los 90. También hay solo un pequeño grupo de voluntarios que han tenido muy poco tiempo para dedicarlo a mejorar esta API.

The C-structure corresponding to an object of PyArrayIter_Type is the PyArrayIterObject. The PyArrayIterObject is used to keep track of a pointer into an N-dimensional array. It contains associated information used to quickly march through the array. The pointer can be adjusted in three basic ways: 1) advance to the “next” position in the array in a C-style contiguous fashion, 2) advance to an arbitrary N-dimensional coordinate in the array, and 3) advance to an arbitrary one-dimensional index into the array. The members of the PyArrayIterObject structure are used in these calculations. Iterator objects keep their own dimension and strides information about an array. This can be adjusted as needed for “broadcasting,” or to loop over only specific dimensions.
trans-unit.target: La estructura C correspondiente a un objeto de PyArrayIter_Type es PyArrayIterObject . El PyArrayIterObject se utiliza para seguir la pista de un puntero en una matriz N-dimensional. Contiene información asociada que se utiliza para recorrer rápidamente la matriz. El puntero se puede ajustar de tres formas básicas: 1) avanzar a la posición "siguiente" en la matriz en una forma contigua de estilo C, 2) avanzar a una coordenada N-dimensional arbitraria en la matriz, y 3) avanzar a una índice unidimensional arbitrario en la matriz. Los miembros del PyArrayIterObject estructura se utilizan en estos cálculos. Los objetos iteradores mantienen su propia dimensión y avanzan la información sobre una matriz. Esto se puede ajustar según sea necesario para "transmisión" o para realizar un bucle solo en dimensiones específicas.

trans-unit.source: The Chebyshev points of the first kind are the points cos(x), where x = [pi*(k + .5)/npts for k in range(npts)].
The Chebyshev points of the first kind.
The Chebyshev points of the second kind are the points cos(x), where x = [pi*k/(npts - 1) for k in range(npts)].
The Chebyshev points of the second kind.

The Chebyshev polynomials used in the interpolation are orthogonal when sampled at the Chebyshev points of the first kind. If it is desired to constrain some of the coefficients they can simply be set to the desired value after the interpolation, no new interpolation or fit is needed. This is especially useful if it is known apriori that some of coefficients are zero. For instance, if the function is even then the coefficients of the terms of odd degree in the result can be set to zero.
The Chebyshev series basis polynomials aren’t powers of x so the results of this function may seem unintuitive.
trans-unit.target: Los polinomios de base de la serie de Chebyshev no son potencias de x , por lo que los resultados de esta función pueden parecer poco intuitivos.

trans-unit.source: The Code of Conduct Committee should aim to have a resolution agreed upon within two weeks. In the event that a resolution can’t be determined in that time, the committee will respond to the reporter(s) with an update and projected timeline for resolution.
The Code of Conduct Committee will formally review and sign off on all cases where this mechanism has been applied to make sure it is not being used to control ordinary heated disagreement.

The Council can create subcommittees that provide leadership and guidance for specific aspects of the project. Like the Council as a whole, subcommittees should conduct their business in an open and public manner unless privacy is specifically called for. Private subcommittee communications should happen on the main private mailing list of the Council unless specifically called for.

The Council reserves the right to eject current Members, if they are deemed to be actively harmful to the project’s well-being, and attempts at communication and conflict resolution have failed. This requires the consensus of the remaining Members.
The Council will maintain one narrowly focused subcommittee to manage its interactions with NumFOCUS.

trans-unit.source: The F statistic is used to compare in-group variances to between-group variances. Calculating the distribution depends on the sampling, and so it is a function of the respective degrees of freedom in the problem. The variable dfnum is the number of samples minus one, the between-groups degrees of freedom, while dfden is the within-groups degrees of freedom, the sum of the number of samples in each group minus the number of groups.
trans-unit.target: La estadística F se utiliza para comparar las variaciones dentro del grupo con las variaciones entre grupos. El cálculo de la distribución depende del muestreo, por lo que es función de los respectivos grados de libertad en el problema. La variable dfnum es el número de muestras menos uno, los grados de libertad entre grupos, mientras que dfden son los grados de libertad dentro de los grupos, la suma del número de muestras en cada grupo menos el número de grupos.

The Gamma distribution is often used to model the times to failure of electronic components, and arises naturally in processes for which the waiting times between Poisson distributed events are relevant.
trans-unit.target: La distribución Gamma se utiliza a menudo para modelar los tiempos hasta el fallo de los componentes electrónicos,y surge de forma natural en procesos para los que son relevantes los tiempos de espera entre los eventos distribuidos por Poisson.

trans-unit.source: The Generator’s normal, exponential and gamma functions use 256-step Ziggurat methods which are 2-10 times faster than NumPy’s Box-Muller or inverse CDF implementations.
trans-unit.target: Las funciones normales, exponenciales y gamma del generador utilizan métodos Ziggurat de 256 pasos que son de 2 a 10 veces más rápidos que las implementaciones Box-Muller o CDF inversa de NumPy.

trans-unit.source: The Gumbel (named for German mathematician Emil Julius Gumbel) was used very early in the hydrology literature, for modeling the occurrence of flood events. It is also used for modeling maximum wind speed and rainfall rates. It is a “fat-tailed” distribution - the probability of an event in the tail of the distribution is larger than if one used a Gaussian, hence the surprisingly frequent occurrence of 100-year floods. Floods were initially modeled as a Gaussian process, which underestimated the frequency of extreme events.
trans-unit.target: El Gumbel (llamado así por el matemático alemán Emil Julius Gumbel) se usó muy temprano en la literatura de hidrología para modelar la ocurrencia de eventos de inundación. También se utiliza para modelar la velocidad máxima del viento y las tasas de lluvia. Es una distribución de “cola gruesa”: la probabilidad de un evento en la cola de la distribución es mayor que si se usara una gaussiana, de ahí la ocurrencia sorprendentemente frecuente de inundaciones de 100 años. Las inundaciones se modelaron inicialmente como un proceso gaussiano, que subestimó la frecuencia de eventos extremos.

trans-unit.source: The Gumbel (or Smallest Extreme Value (SEV) or the Smallest Extreme Value Type I) distribution is one of a class of Generalized Extreme Value (GEV) distributions used in modeling extreme value problems. The Gumbel is a special case of the Extreme Value Type I distribution for maximums from distributions with “exponential-like” tails.
trans-unit.target: La distribución Gumbel (o el valor extremo más pequeño (SEV) o el valor extremo más pequeño tipo I) pertenece a una clase de distribuciones de valor extremo generalizado (GEV) que se utilizan para modelar problemas de valores extremos. El Gumbel es un caso especial de la distribución de Valor Extremo Tipo I para máximos de distribuciones con colas "exponenciales".

trans-unit.source: The Hamming was named for R. W. Hamming, an associate of J. W. Tukey and is described in Blackman and Tukey. It was recommended for smoothing the truncated autocovariance function in the time domain. Most references to the Hamming window come from the signal processing literature, where it is used as one of many windowing functions for smoothing values. It is also known as an apodization (which means “removing the foot”, i.e. smoothing discontinuities at the beginning and end of the sampled signal) or tapering function.
trans-unit.target: El Hamming recibió su nombre de RW Hamming, un asociado de JW Tukey y se describe en Blackman y Tukey. Se recomendó para suavizar la función de autocovarianza truncada en el dominio del tiempo. La mayoría de las referencias a la ventana de Hamming provienen de la literatura de procesamiento de señales, donde se utiliza como una de las muchas funciones de ventana para suavizar valores. También se conoce como apodización (que significa "quitar el pie", es decir, suavizar las discontinuidades al principio y al final de la señal muestreada) o función de afilado.

trans-unit.source: The Kaiser was named for Jim Kaiser, who discovered a simple approximation to the DPSS window based on Bessel functions. The Kaiser window is a very good approximation to the Digital Prolate Spheroidal Sequence, or Slepian window, which is the transform which maximizes the energy in the main lobe of the window relative to total energy.

trans-unit.source: The Logistic distribution is used in Extreme Value problems where it can act as a mixture of Gumbel distributions, in Epidemiology, and by the World Chess Federation (FIDE) where it is used in the Elo ranking system, assuming the performance of each player is a logistically distributed random variable.
trans-unit.target: La distribución logística se utiliza en los problemas de Valor Extremo,donde puede actuar como una mezcla de distribuciones de Gumbel,en Epidemiología,y por la Federación Mundial de Ajedrez (FIDE)donde se utiliza en el sistema de clasificación Elo,suponiendo que el rendimiento de cada jugador es una variable aleatoria distribuida logísticamente.

trans-unit.source: The Lomax or Pareto II distribution is a shifted Pareto distribution. The classical Pareto distribution can be obtained from the Lomax distribution by adding 1 and multiplying by the scale parameter m (see Notes). The smallest value of the Lomax distribution is zero while for the classical Pareto distribution it is mu, where the standard Pareto distribution has location mu = 1. Lomax can also be considered as a simplified version of the Generalized Pareto distribution (available in SciPy), with the scale set to one and the location set to zero.
trans-unit.target: La distribución de Lomax o Pareto II es una distribución de Pareto desplazada. La distribución clásica de Pareto se puede obtener a partir de la distribución de Lomax sumando 1 y multiplicando por el parámetro de escala m (ver Notas). El valor más pequeño de la distribución de Lomax es cero, mientras que para la distribución de Pareto clásica es mu , donde la distribución de Pareto estándar tiene la ubicación mu = 1 . Lomax también se puede considerar como una versión simplificada de la distribución de Pareto generalizada (disponible en SciPy), con la escala establecida en uno y la ubicación establecida en cero.

trans-unit.source: The NumPy histogram function applied to an array returns a pair of vectors: the histogram of the array and a vector of the bin edges. Beware: matplotlib also has a function to build histograms (called hist, as in Matlab) that differs from the one in NumPy. The main difference is that pylab.hist plots the histogram automatically, while numpy.histogram only generates the data.

The NumPy C coding conventions are based on Python PEP-0007 by Guido van Rossum with a few added strictures. There are many C coding conventions and it must be emphasized that the primary goal of the NumPy conventions isn’t to choose the ‘best’, about which there is certain to be disagreement, but to achieve uniformity. Because the NumPy conventions are very close to those in PEP-0007, that PEP is used as a template below with the NumPy additions and variations in the appropriate spots.

The NumPy Project (The Project) is an open source software project affiliated with the 501(c)3 NumFOCUS Foundation. The goal of The Project is to develop open source software for array-based computing in Python, and in particular the numpy package, along with related software such as f2py and the NumPy Sphinx extensions. The Software developed by The Project is released under the BSD (or similar) open source license, developed openly and hosted on public GitHub repositories under the numpy GitHub organization.

The NumPy library contains multidimensional array and matrix data structures (you’ll find more information about this in later sections). It provides ndarray, a homogeneous n-dimensional array object, with methods to efficiently operate on it. NumPy can be used to perform a wide variety of mathematical operations on arrays. It adds powerful data structures to Python that guarantee efficient calculations with arrays and matrices and it supplies an enormous library of high-level mathematical functions that operate on these arrays and matrices.

The NumPy linear algebra functions rely on BLAS and LAPACK to provide efficient low level implementations of standard linear algebra algorithms. Those libraries may be provided by NumPy itself using C versions of a subset of their reference implementations but, when possible, highly optimized libraries that take advantage of specialized processor functionality are preferred. Examples of such libraries are OpenBLAS, MKL (TM), and ATLAS. Because those libraries are multithreaded and processor dependent, environmental variables and external packages such as threadpoolctl may be needed to control the number of threads or specify the processor architecture.
trans-unit.target: Las funciones de álgebra lineal de NumPy se basan en BLAS y LAPACK para proporcionar implementaciones eficientes de bajo nivel de algoritmos de álgebra lineal estándar. Esas bibliotecas pueden ser proporcionadas por el propio NumPy usando versiones C de un subconjunto de sus implementaciones de referencia pero, cuando es posible, se prefieren las bibliotecas altamente optimizadas que aprovechan la funcionalidad del procesador especializado. Ejemplos de tales bibliotecas son OpenBLAS , MKL (TM) y ATLAS. Debido a que esas bibliotecas son multiproceso y dependen del procesador, es posible que se necesiten variables ambientales y paquetes externos como threadpoolctl para controlar el número de subprocesos o especificar la arquitectura del procesador.

trans-unit.source: The NumPy project welcomes and encourages participation by everyone. We are committed to being a community that everyone enjoys being part of. Although we may not always be able to accommodate each individual’s preferences, we try our best to treat everyone kindly.

The NumPy source code includes an example of a custom data-type as part of its test suite. The file _rational_tests.c.src in the source code directory numpy/numpy/core/src/umath/ contains an implementation of a data-type that represents a rational number as the ratio of two 32 bit integers.

The Pareto distribution must be greater than zero, and is unbounded above. It is also known as the “80-20 rule”. In this distribution, 80 percent of the weights are in the lowest 20 percent of the range, while the other 20 percent fill the remaining 80 percent of the range.
trans-unit.target: La distribución de Pareto debe ser mayor que cero y no tiene límites arriba. También se conoce como la "regla 80-20". En esta distribución, el 80 por ciento de los pesos están en el 20 por ciento más bajo del rango, mientras que el otro 20 por ciento llena el 80 por ciento restante del rango.

trans-unit.source: The Pareto distribution, named after the Italian economist Vilfredo Pareto, is a power law probability distribution useful in many real world problems. Outside the field of economics it is generally referred to as the Bradford distribution. Pareto developed the distribution to describe the distribution of wealth in an economy. It has also found use in insurance, web page access statistics, oil field sizes, and many other problems, including the download frequency for projects in Sourceforge [1]. It is one of the so-called “fat-tailed” distributions.

trans-unit.source: The Project

The Project Community consists of all Contributors and Users of the Project. Contributors work on behalf of and are responsible to the larger Project Community and we strive to keep the barrier between Contributors and Users as low as possible.

The Project is developed by a team of distributed developers, called Contributors. Contributors are individuals who have contributed code, documentation, designs or other work to the Project. Anyone can be a Contributor. Contributors can be affiliated with any legal entity or none. Contributors participate in the project by submitting, reviewing and discussing GitHub Pull Requests and Issues and participating in open and public Project discussions on GitHub, mailing lists, and other channels. The foundation of Project participation is openness and transparency.

The Project is formally affiliated with the 501(c)3 NumFOCUS Foundation (http://numfocus.org), which serves as its fiscal sponsor, may hold project trademarks and other intellectual property, helps manage project donations and acts as a parent legal entity. NumFOCUS is the only legal entity that has a formal relationship with the project (see Institutional Partners section below).

The Project will have a Steering Council that consists of Project Contributors who have produced contributions that are substantial in quality and quantity, and sustained over at least one year. The overall role of the Council is to ensure, with input from the Community, the long-term well-being of the project, both technically and as a community.

trans-unit.source: The Python exposure supplies two iteration interfaces, one which follows the Python iterator protocol, and another which mirrors the C-style do-while pattern. The native Python approach is better in most cases, but if you need the coordinates or index of an iterator, use the C-style pattern.
trans-unit.target: La exposición a Python suministra dos interfaces de iteración,una que sigue el protocolo del iterador de Python,y otra que refleja el patrón de iteración de estilo C.El enfoque nativo de Python es mejor en la mayoría de los casos,pero si necesitas las coordenadas o el índice de un iterador,usa el patrón de estilo C.

trans-unit.source: The Python function max() will find the maximum over a one-dimensional array, but it will do so using a slower sequence interface. The reduce method of the maximum ufunc is much faster. Also, the max() method will not give answers you might expect for arrays with greater than one dimension. The reduce method of minimum also allows you to compute a total minimum over an array.
trans-unit.target: La función de Python max() encontrará el máximo en una matriz unidimensional, pero lo hará usando una interfaz de secuencia más lenta. El método de reducción del máximo ufunc es mucho más rápido. Además, el método max() no dará las respuestas que podría esperar para matrices con más de una dimensión. El método de reducción de mínimo también le permite calcular un mínimo total sobre una matriz.

trans-unit.source: The Python iterator protocol doesn’t have a natural way to query these additional values from the iterator, so we introduce an alternate syntax for iterating with an nditer. This syntax explicitly works with the iterator object itself, so its properties are readily accessible during iteration. With this looping construct, the current value is accessible by indexing into the iterator, and the index being tracked is the property index or multi_index depending on what was requested.
trans-unit.target: El protocolo del iterador de Python no tiene una forma natural de consultar estos valores adicionales del iterador, por lo que presentamos una sintaxis alternativa para iterar con un nditer . Esta sintaxis funciona explícitamente con el objeto iterador en sí, por lo que sus propiedades son fácilmente accesibles durante la iteración. Con esta construcción de bucle, se puede acceder al valor actual indexando en el iterador, y el índice que se rastrea es el index propiedad o multi_index , según lo que se solicitó.

trans-unit.source: The SciPy Code of Conduct

The SciPy library also contains a linalg submodule, and there is overlap in the functionality provided by the SciPy and NumPy submodules. SciPy contains functions not found in numpy.linalg, such as functions related to LU decomposition and the Schur decomposition, multiple ways of calculating the pseudoinverse, and matrix transcendentals such as the matrix logarithm. Some functions that exist in both have augmented functionality in scipy.linalg. For example, scipy.linalg.eig can take a second matrix argument for solving generalized eigenvalue problems. Some functions in NumPy, however, have more flexible broadcasting options. For example, numpy.linalg.solve can handle “stacked” arrays, while scipy.linalg.solve accepts only a single square array as its first argument.

trans-unit.source: The Zipf distribution (also known as the zeta distribution) is a continuous probability distribution that satisfies Zipf’s law: the frequency of an item is inversely proportional to its rank in a frequency table.
trans-unit.target: La distribución de Zipf (también conocida como distribución zeta) es una distribución de probabilidad continua que satisface la ley de Zipf: la frecuencia de un elemento es inversamente proporcional a su rango en una tabla de frecuencias.

trans-unit.source: The above does not hold for in-place operators, for which ndarray never returns NotImplemented. Hence, arr += obj would always lead to a TypeError. This is because for arrays in-place operations cannot generically be replaced by a simple reverse operation. (For instance, by default, arr += obj would be translated to arr = arr + obj, i.e., arr would be replaced, contrary to what is expected for in-place array operations.)
trans-unit.target: Lo anterior no es ndarray para los operadores in situ, para los que ndarray nunca devuelve NotImplemented . Por lo tanto, arr += obj siempre conduciría a un TypeError . Esto se debe a que, en el caso de las matrices, las operaciones in situ no pueden sustituirse genéricamente por una simple operación inversa. (Por ejemplo, de forma predeterminada, arr += obj se traduciría a arr = arr + obj , es decir, arr se reemplazaría, al contrario de lo que se espera para las operaciones de matriz in situ).

trans-unit.source: The advantage of the hand-generated wrapper is that you have complete control over how the C-library gets used and called which can lead to a lean and tight interface with minimal over-head. The disadvantage is that you have to write, debug, and maintain C-code, although most of it can be adapted using the time-honored technique of “cutting-pasting-and-modifying” from other extension modules. Because, the procedure of calling out to additional C-code is fairly regimented, code-generation procedures have been developed to make this process easier. One of these code-generation techniques is distributed with NumPy and allows easy integration with Fortran and (simple) C code. This package, f2py, will be covered briefly in the next section.

The advantage of this creation function is that one can guarantee the number of elements and the starting and end point, which arange() generally will not do for arbitrary start, stop, and step values.

The advantage of this version of reduce compared to the normal ufunc.reduce is that it makes use of the Broadcasting Rules in order to avoid creating an argument array the size of the output times the number of vectors.

The advantages over random generation include tools to replay and share failures without requiring a fixed seed, reporting minimal examples for each failure, and better-than-naive-random techniques for triggering bugs.

trans-unit.source: The algorithm is carefully designed to eliminate a number of possible ways to collide. For example, if one only does one level of spawning, it is guaranteed that all states will be unique. But it’s easier to estimate the naive upper bound on a napkin and take comfort knowing that the probability is actually lower.
trans-unit.target: El algoritmo está cuidadosamente diseñado para eliminar una serie de posibles formas de colisión. Por ejemplo, si uno solo hace un nivel de desove, se garantiza que todos los estados serán únicos. Pero es más fácil estimar el límite superior ingenuo en una servilleta y sentirse cómodo sabiendo que la probabilidad es en realidad menor.

trans-unit.source: The algorithm relies on computing the eigenvalues of the companion matrix [1].
trans-unit.target: El algoritmo se basa en calcular los valores propios de la matriz acompañante [1] .

trans-unit.source: The algorithm works by first finding a “running dimension”, along which the blocks will be extracted. Given an array of dimensions (d1, d2, ..., dn), e.g. if buf_size is smaller than d1, the first dimension will be used. If, on the other hand, d1 < buf_size < d1*d2 the second dimension will be used, and so on. Blocks are extracted along this dimension, and when the last block is returned the process continues from the next dimension, until all elements have been read.
trans-unit.target: El algoritmo funciona encontrando primero una "dimensión de ejecución", a lo largo de la cual se extraerán los bloques. Dada una matriz de dimensiones (d1, d2, ..., dn) , por ejemplo, si buf_size es menor que d1 , se utilizará la primera dimensión. Si, por otro lado, d1 < buf_size < d1*d2 se utilizará la segunda dimensión, y así sucesivamente. Los bloques se extraen a lo largo de esta dimensión, y cuando se devuelve el último bloque, el proceso continúa desde la siguiente dimensión, hasta que se hayan leído todos los elementos.

trans-unit.source: The angle of the ray intersecting the unit circle at the given x-coordinate in radians [0, pi]. This is a scalar if x is a scalar.
trans-unit.target: El ángulo del rayo que interseca el círculo unitario en la coordenada x dada en radianes [0, pi]. Este es un escalar si x es un escalar.

trans-unit.source: The anti-diagonal can be filled by reversing the order of elements using either numpy.flipud or numpy.fliplr.
trans-unit.target: El anti-diagonal se puede completar invirtiendo el orden de los elementos usando numpy.flipud o numpy.fliplr .

trans-unit.source: The anti-diagonal can be obtained by reversing the order of elements using either numpy.flipud or numpy.fliplr.
trans-unit.target: La anti-diagonal se puede obtener invirtiendo el orden de los elementos usando numpy.flipud o numpy.fliplr .

trans-unit.source: The approximate decimal resolution of this type, i.e., 10**-precision.
trans-unit.target: La resolución decimal aproximada de este tipo, es decir, 10**-precision .

trans-unit.source: The approximate number of decimal digits to which this kind of float is precise.
trans-unit.target: El número aproximado de dígitos decimales con los que este tipo de carroza es preciso.

trans-unit.source: The argument is considered as a return variable. It is appended to the <returned variables> list. Using intent(out) sets intent(hide) automatically, unless also intent(in) or intent(inout) were used.
The argument is considered as an input-only argument. It means that the value of the argument is passed to Fortran/C function and that function is expected not to change the value of an argument.

The argument is considered as an input/output or in situ output argument. intent(inout) arguments can be only “contiguous” NumPy arrays with proper type and size. Here “contiguous” can be either in Fortran or C sense. The latter one coincides with the contiguous concept used in NumPy and is effective only if intent(c) is used. Fortran contiguity is assumed by default.

The argument is considered as an input/output or in situ output argument. intent(inplace) arguments must be NumPy arrays with proper size. If the type of an array is not “proper” or the array is non-contiguous then the array will be changed in-place to fix the type and make it contiguous.

The argument is removed from the list of required or optional arguments. Typically intent(hide) is used with intent(out) or when <init_expr> completely determines the value of the argument like in the following example:

The argument is treated as a C scalar or C array argument. In the case of a scalar argument, its value is passed to C function as a C scalar argument (recall that Fortran scalar arguments are actually C pointer arguments). In the case of an array argument, the wrapper function is assumed to treat multidimensional arrays as C-contiguous arrays.

The argument is treated as a junk of memory. No Fortran nor C contiguity checks are carried out. Using intent(cache) makes sense only for array arguments, also in connection with intent(hide) or optional attributes.

The arguments ngood and nbad each must be less than 10**9. For extremely large arguments, the algorithm that is used to compute the samples [4] breaks down because of loss of precision in floating point calculations. For such large values, if nsample is not also large, the distribution can be approximated with the binomial distribution, binomial(n=nsample, p=ngood/(ngood + nbad)).
trans-unit.target: Los argumentos ngood y nbad deben ser inferiores a 10**9 . Para argumentos extremadamente grandes, el algoritmo que se utiliza para calcular las muestras [4] falla debido a la pérdida de precisión en los cálculos de coma flotante. Para valores tan grandes, si nsample no es también grande, la distribución se puede aproximar con la distribución binomial(n=nsample, p=ngood/(ngood + nbad)) , binomial (n = nsample, p = ngood / (ngood + nbad)) .

trans-unit.source: The arguments of the configuration function specify the name of parent SciPy package (parent_package) and the directory location of the main setup.py script (top_path). These arguments, along with the name of the current package, should be passed to the Configuration constructor.
trans-unit.target: Los argumentos de la función de configuration especifican el nombre del paquete SciPy principal ( parent_package ) y la ubicación del directorio del script setup.py principal ( top_path ). Estos argumentos, junto con el nombre del paquete actual, deben pasarse al constructor de Configuration .

The arithmetic mean is the sum of the elements along the axis divided by the number of elements.
trans-unit.target: La media aritmética es la suma de los elementos a lo largo del eje dividida por el número de elementos.

trans-unit.source: The arithmetic mean is the sum of the non-NaN elements along the axis divided by the number of non-NaN elements.
trans-unit.target: La media aritmética es la suma de los elementos no-NaN a lo largo del eje dividida por el número de elementos no-NaN.

trans-unit.source: The array v of eigenvectors may not be of maximum rank, that is, some of the columns may be linearly dependent, although round-off error may obscure that fact. If the eigenvalues are all different, then theoretically the eigenvectors are linearly independent and a can be diagonalized by a similarity transformation using v, i.e, inv(v) @ a @ v is diagonal.

The array v of eigenvectors may not be of maximum rank, that is, some of the columns may be linearly dependent, although round-off error may obscure that fact. If the eigenvalues are all different, then theoretically the eigenvectors are linearly independent. Likewise, the (complex-valued) matrix of eigenvectors v is unitary if the matrix a is normal, i.e., if dot(a, a.H) = dot(a.H, a), where a.H denotes the conjugate transpose of a.
trans-unit.target: La matriz v de vectores propios puede no ser de rango máximo, es decir, algunas de las columnas pueden ser linealmente dependientes, aunque el error de redondeo puede ocultar ese hecho. Si los valores propios son todos diferentes, entonces, teóricamente, los vectores propios son linealmente independientes. Asimismo, la matriz (de valor complejo) de autovectores v es unitaria si la matriz a es normal, es decir, si dot(a, a.H) = dot(a.H, a) , donde a.H denota la transpuesta conjugada de a .

trans-unit.source: The array function protocol which allows array-like objects to hook into the NumPy API is currently enabled by default. This option exists since NumPy 1.16 and is enabled by default since NumPy 1.17. It can be disabled using:
The array h contains the Householder reflectors that generate q along with r. The tau array contains scaling factors for the reflectors. In the deprecated ‘economic’ mode only h is returned.

trans-unit.source: The array interface (sometimes called array protocol) was created in 2005 as a means for array-like Python objects to re-use each other’s data buffers intelligently whenever possible. The homogeneous N-dimensional array interface is a default mechanism for objects to share N-dimensional array memory and information. The interface consists of a Python-side and a C-side using two attributes. Objects wishing to be considered an N-dimensional array in application code should support at least one of these attributes. Objects wishing to support an N-dimensional array in application code should look for at least one of these attributes and use the information provided appropriately.
trans-unit.target: La interfaz de matriz (a veces llamada protocolo de matriz) se creó en 2005 como un medio para que los objetos Python similares a matrices reutilicen los búferes de datos de los demás de manera inteligente siempre que sea posible. La interfaz de matriz N-dimensional homogénea es un mecanismo predeterminado para que los objetos compartan memoria e información de matriz N-dimensional. La interfaz consta de un lado Python y un lado C usando dos atributos. Los objetos que deseen ser considerados una matriz N-dimensional en el código de la aplicación deben admitir al menos uno de estos atributos. Los objetos que deseen admitir una matriz N-dimensional en el código de la aplicación deben buscar al menos uno de estos atributos y utilizar la información proporcionada de forma adecuada.

trans-unit.source: The array scalar objects have an array priority of NPY_SCALAR_PRIORITY (-1,000,000.0). They also do not (yet) have a ctypes attribute. Otherwise, they share the same attributes as arrays:

The array scalars also offer the same methods and attributes as arrays with the intent that the same code can be used to support arbitrary dimensions (including 0-dimensions). The array scalars are read-only (immutable) with the exception of the void scalar which can also be written to so that structured array field setting works more naturally (a[0][‘f1’] = value ).
trans-unit.target: Los escalares de matriz también ofrecen los mismos métodos y atributos que las matrices con la intención de que se pueda usar el mismo código para admitir dimensiones arbitrarias (incluidas las dimensiones 0). Los escalares de la matriz se-de sólo lectura (inmutable) con la excepción del escalar vacío que también se puede escribir de modo que la fijación de campo de matriz estructurada funciona de forma más natural (a [0] [ 'F1'] = value ).

trans-unit.source: The array scalars offer a hierarchy of Python types that allow a one- to-one correspondence between the data-type stored in an array and the Python-type that is returned when an element is extracted from the array. An exception to this rule was made with object arrays. Object arrays are heterogeneous collections of arbitrary Python objects. When you select an item from an object array, you get back the original Python object (and not an object array scalar which does exist but is rarely used for practical purposes).
trans-unit.target: Los escalares de la matriz ofrecen una jerarquía de tipos de pitón que permiten una correspondencia de uno a uno entre el tipo de datos almacenados en una matriz y el tipo de pitón que se devuelve cuando se extrae un elemento de la matriz.Una excepción a esta regla se hizo con los arreglos de objetos.Las matrices de objetos son colecciones heterogéneas de objetos Python arbitrarios.Cuando se selecciona un elemento de una matriz de objetos,se recupera el objeto Python original (y no un escalar de matriz de objetos que existe pero que raramente se utiliza para fines prácticos).

trans-unit.source: The average along the specified axis. When returned is True, return a tuple with the average as the first element and the sum of the weights as the second element. The return type is np.float64 if a is of integer type and floats smaller than float64, or the input data-type, otherwise. If returned, sum_of_weights is always float64.
trans-unit.target: El promedio a lo largo del eje especificado. Cuando devuelto es True , devuelve una tupla con el promedio como primer elemento y la suma de los pesos como segundo elemento. El tipo de retorno es np.float64 si a es de tipo entero y flota más pequeño que float64 , o el tipo de datos de entrada, de lo contrario. Si se devuelve, sum_of_weights siempre es float64 .

trans-unit.source: The average squared deviation is normally calculated as x.sum() / N, where N = len(x). If, however, ddof is specified, the divisor N - ddof is used instead. In standard statistical practice, ddof=1 provides an unbiased estimator of the variance of the infinite population. ddof=0 provides a maximum likelihood estimate of the variance for normally distributed variables. The standard deviation computed in this function is the square root of the estimated variance, so even with ddof=1, it will not be an unbiased estimate of the standard deviation per se.
trans-unit.target: La desviación cuadrática media se calcula normalmente como x.sum() / N , donde N = len(x) . Sin embargo, ddof se especifica ddof , en su lugar se utiliza el divisor N - ddof . En la práctica estadística estándar, ddof=1 proporciona un estimador insesgado de la varianza de la población infinita. ddof=0 proporciona una estimación de máxima verosimilitud de la varianza para variables distribuidas normalmente. La desviación estándar calculada en esta función es la raíz cuadrada de la varianza estimada, por lo que incluso con ddof=1 , no será una estimación insesgada de la desviación estándar per se.

trans-unit.target: El eje a lo largo del cual eliminar el subarreglo definido por obj . Si el axis es Ninguno, obj se aplica a la matriz aplanada.

trans-unit.source: The axis is rolled until it lies before this position. The default, 0, results in a “complete” roll.
trans-unit.target: El eje se rueda hasta que se encuentra antes de esta posición. El valor predeterminado, 0, da como resultado una tirada "completa".

trans-unit.source: The axis to be rolled. The positions of the other axes do not change relative to one another.

The axis to operate on. If None, ar will be flattened. If an integer, the subarrays indexed by the given axis will be flattened and treated as the elements of a 1-D array with the dimension of the given axis, see the notes for more details. trans-unit.source: The basis polynomials are scaled so that the companion matrix is symmetric when c is a Chebyshev basis polynomial. The behaviour of NumPy and Python integer types differs significantly for integer overflows and may confuse users expecting NumPy integers to behave similar to Python’s int. Unlike NumPy, the size of Python’s int is flexible. This means Python integers may expand to accommodate any integer and will not overflow.

trans-unit.source: The best strategy to better understand the code base is to pick something you want to change and start reading the code to figure out how it works. When in doubt, you can ask questions on the mailing list. It is perfectly okay if your pull requests aren’t perfect, the community is always happy to help. As a volunteer project, things do sometimes get dropped and it’s totally fine to ping us if something has sat without a response for about two to four weeks.

trans-unit.source: The biggest difficulty when writing extension modules is reference counting. It is an important reason for the popularity of f2py, weave, Cython, ctypes, etc…. If you mis-handle reference counts you can get problems from memory-leaks to segmentation faults. The only strategy I know of to handle reference counts correctly is blood, sweat, and tears. First, you force it into your head that every Python variable has a reference count. Then, you understand exactly what each function does to the reference count of your objects, so that you can properly use DECREF and INCREF when you need them. Reference counting can really test the amount of patience and diligence you have towards your programming craft. Despite the grim depiction, most cases of reference counting are quite straightforward with the most common difficulty being not using DECREF on objects before exiting early from a routine due to some error. In second place, is the common error of not owning the reference on an object that is passed to a function or macro that is going to steal the reference ( e.g.PyTuple_SET_ITEM, and most functions that take PyArray_Descr objects).
The bin edges along the first dimension.

trans-unit.source: The binwidth is proportional to the interquartile range (IQR) and inversely proportional to cube root of a.size. Can be too conservative for small datasets, but is quite good for large datasets. The IQR is very robust to outliers.
trans-unit.target: El ancho del bin es proporcional al rango intercuartil (IQR)e inversamente proporcional a la raíz cúbica del tamaño a.Puede ser demasiado conservador para pequeños conjuntos de datos,pero es bastante bueno para grandes conjuntos de datos.El IQR es muy robusto para los valores atípicos.

trans-unit.source: The binwidth is proportional to the standard deviation of the data and inversely proportional to cube root of x.size. Can be too conservative for small datasets, but is quite good for large datasets. The standard deviation is not very robust to outliers. Values are very similar to the Freedman-Diaconis estimator in the absence of outliers.
trans-unit.target: El binwidth es proporcional a la desviación estándar de los datos e inversamente proporcional a la raíz cúbica de x.size . Puede ser demasiado conservador para conjuntos de datos pequeños, pero es bastante bueno para conjuntos de datos grandes. La desviación estándar no es muy robusta a valores atípicos. Los valores son muy similares al estimador de Freedman-Diaconis en ausencia de valores atípicos.

The bit-wise operators & and | are the proper way to perform element-by-element array comparisons. Be sure you understand the operator precedence: (a > 2) & (a < 5) is the proper syntax because a > 2 & a < 5 will result in an error due to the fact that 2 & a is evaluated first.

Asegúrese de comprender la precedencia del operador: (a > 2) & (a < 5) es la sintaxis adecuada porque a > 2 & a < 5 dará como resultado un error debido al hecho de que 2 & a se evalúa primero.

Specifically, when increasing is False, the i-th output column is the input vector raised element-wise to the power of N - i - 1. Such a matrix with a geometric progression in each row is named for Alexandre- Theophile Vandermonde.

Esta matriz con una progresión geométrica en cada fila lleva el nombre de Alexandre-Theophile Vandermonde.

The committee will never publicly discuss the issue; all public statements will be made by the chair of the Code of Conduct Committee or the NumPy Steering Council.
The committee will respond to any report as soon as possible, and at most within 72 hours.
The committee will then review the incident and determine, to the best of their ability:

trans-unit.source: The concept of a behaved segment is used in the description of the function pointers. A behaved segment is one that is aligned and in native machine byte-order for the data-type. The nonzero, copyswap, copyswapn, getitem, and setitem functions can (and must) deal with mis-behaved arrays. The other functions require behaved memory segments.
trans-unit.target: El concepto de segmento con comportamiento se utiliza en la descripción de los punteros de función. Un segmento con comportamiento es uno que está alineado y en el orden de bytes de la máquina nativa para el tipo de datos. Las copyswap nonzero , copyswap , copyswapn , getitem y setitem pueden (y deben) lidiar con matrices con mal comportamiento. Las otras funciones requieren segmentos de memoria con comportamiento.

trans-unit.source: The condition number of x is defined as the norm of x times the norm of the inverse of x[1]; the norm can be the usual L2-norm (root-of-sum-of-squares) or one of a number of other matrix norms.
trans-unit.target: El número de condición de x se define como la norma de x multiplicada por la norma de la inversa de x [1] ; la norma puede ser la norma L2 habitual (raíz de suma de cuadrados) o una de varias otras normas matriciales.

trans-unit.source: The convolution operator is often seen in signal processing, where it models the effect of a linear time-invariant system on a signal [1]. In probability theory, the sum of two independent random variables is distributed according to the convolution of their individual distributions.
trans-unit.target: El operador de convolución se ve a menudo en el procesamiento de señales, donde modela el efecto de un sistema lineal invariante en el tiempo sobre una señal [1] . En la teoría de la probabilidad, la suma de dos variables aleatorias independientes se distribuye de acuerdo con la convolución de sus distribuciones individuales.

trans-unit.source: The correct interpretation of the hermitian input depends on the length of the original data, as given by n. This is because each input shape could correspond to either an odd or even length signal. By default, hfft assumes an even output length which puts the last entry at the Nyquist frequency; aliasing with its symmetric counterpart. By Hermitian symmetry, the value is thus treated as purely real. To avoid losing information, the shape of the full signal must be given.

The correct interpretation of the hermitian input depends on the length of the original data, as given by n. This is because each input shape could correspond to either an odd or even length signal. By default, irfft assumes an even output length which puts the last entry at the Nyquist frequency; aliasing with its symmetric counterpart. By Hermitian symmetry, the value is thus treated as purely real. To avoid losing information, the correct length of the real input must be given.

The correct interpretation of the hermitian input depends on the shape of the original data, as given by s. This is because each input shape could correspond to either an odd or even length signal. By default, irfftn assumes an even output length which puts the last entry at the Nyquist frequency; aliasing with its symmetric counterpart. When performing the final complex to real transform, the last value is thus treated as purely real. To avoid losing information, the correct shape of the real input must be given.

trans-unit.source: The cov input is used to compute a factor matrix A such that A @ A.T = cov. This argument is used to select the method used to compute the factor matrix A. The default method ‘svd’ is the slowest, while ‘cholesky’ is the fastest but less robust than the slowest method. The method eigh uses eigen decomposition to compute A and is faster than svd but slower than cholesky.

trans-unit.source: The ctypes attribute of an ndarray is also endowed with additional attributes that may be convenient when passing additional information about the array into a ctypes function. The attributes data, shape, and strides can provide ctypes compatible types corresponding to the data-area, the shape, and the strides of the array. The data attribute returns a c_void_p representing a pointer to the data area. The shape and strides attributes each return an array of ctypes integers (or None representing a NULL pointer, if a 0-d array). The base ctype of the array is a ctype integer of the same size as a pointer on the platform. There are also methods data_as({ctype}), shape_as(<base ctype>), and strides_as(<base ctype>). These return the data as a ctype object of your choice and the shape/strides arrays using an underlying base type of your choice. For convenience, the ctypeslib module also contains c_intp as a ctypes integer data-type whose size is the same as the size of c_void_p on the platform (its value is None if ctypes is not installed).

trans-unit.source: The data area can be written to. Setting this to False locks the data, making it read-only. A view (slice, etc.) inherits WRITEABLE from its base array at creation time, but a view of a writeable array may be subsequently locked while the base array remains writeable. (The opposite is not true, in that a view of a locked array may not be made writeable. However, currently, locking a base object does not lock any views that already reference it, so under that circumstance it is possible to alter the contents of a locked array via a previously created writeable view onto it.) Attempting to change a non-writeable array raises a RuntimeError exception.
trans-unit.target: Se puede escribir en el área de datos.Poner esto en falso bloquea los datos,haciéndolos de sólo lectura.Una vista (slice,etc.)hereda WRITEABLE de su matriz base en el momento de la creación,pero una vista de una matriz escribible puede ser bloqueada posteriormente mientras la matriz base sigue siendo escribible.(Lo contrario no es cierto,ya que una vista de una matriz bloqueada puede no hacerse escribible.Sin embargo,actualmente,el bloqueo de un objeto base no bloquea ninguna vista que ya haga referencia a él,por lo que en esa circunstancia es posible alterar el contenido de una matriz bloqueada mediante una vista grabable creada previamente en él).Al intentar cambiar una matriz no escribible se produce una excepción de RuntimeError.

trans-unit.source: The data-type is an important abstraction of the ndarray. Operations will look to the data-type to provide the key functionality that is needed to operate on the array. This functionality is provided in the list of function pointers pointed to by the ‘f’ member of the PyArray_Descr structure. In this way, the number of data-types can be extended simply by providing a PyArray_Descr structure with suitable function pointers in the ‘f’ member. For built-in types there are some optimizations that by-pass this mechanism, but the point of the data- type abstraction is to allow new data-types to be added.
trans-unit.target: El tipo de datos es una abstracción importante del ndarray. Las operaciones buscarán el tipo de datos para proporcionar la funcionalidad clave que se necesita para operar en la matriz. Esta funcionalidad se proporciona en la lista de punteros de función señalados por el miembro 'f' de la estructura PyArray_Descr . De esta manera, el número de tipos de datos se puede extender simplemente proporcionando una estructura PyArray_Descr con punteros de función adecuados en el miembro 'f'. Para los tipos incorporados, hay algunas optimizaciones que eluden este mecanismo, pero el objetivo de la abstracción del tipo de datos es permitir que se agreguen nuevos tipos de datos.

trans-unit.source: The data-type is an important abstraction of the ndarray. Operations will look to the data-type to provide the key functionality that is needed to operate on the array. This functionality is provided in the list of function pointers pointed to by the ‘f’ member of the PyArray_Descr structure. In this way, the number of data-types can be extended simply by providing a PyArray_Descr structure with suitable function pointers in the ‘f’ member. For built-in types there are some optimizations that by-pass this mechanism, but the point of the data- type abstraction is to allow new data-types to be added.

trans-unit.source: The datetime API is experimental in 1.7.0, and may undergo changes in future versions of NumPy.
trans-unit.target: La API de fecha y hora es experimental en 1.7.0 y puede sufrir cambios en futuras versiones de NumPy.

trans-unit.source: The datetime object represents a single moment in time. If two datetimes have different units, they may still be representing the same moment of time, and converting from a bigger unit like months to a smaller unit like days is considered a ‘safe’ cast because the moment of time is still being represented exactly.
trans-unit.target: El objeto de fecha y hora representa un único momento en el tiempo. Si dos fechas y horas tienen unidades diferentes, es posible que sigan representando el mismo momento de tiempo, y la conversión de una unidad más grande, como meses, a una unidad más pequeña, como días, se considera un elenco `` seguro '' porque el momento del tiempo todavía se representa exactamente.

trans-unit.source: The datetime string parser in NumPy 1.6 is very liberal in what it accepts, and silently allows invalid input without raising errors. The parser in NumPy 1.7 is quite strict about only accepting ISO 8601 dates, with a few convenience extensions. 1.6 always creates microsecond (us) units by default, whereas 1.7 detects a unit based on the format of the string. Here is a comparison.:
trans-unit.target: El analizador de cadenas de fecha y hora en NumPy 1.6 es muy liberal en cuanto a lo que acepta,y permite silenciosamente la entrada de datos inválidos sin que se produzcan errores.El analizador en NumPy 1.7 es bastante estricto en cuanto a aceptar sólo fechas ISO 8601,con algunas extensiones de conveniencia.1.6 siempre crea unidades de microsegundos (us)por defecto,mientras que 1.7 detecta una unidad basada en el formato de la cadena.Aquí hay una comparación.:

trans-unit.source: The default interface is a very literal translation of the fortran code into Python. The Fortran array arguments must now be NumPy arrays and the integer argument should be an integer. The interface will attempt to convert all arguments to their required types (and shapes) and issue an error if unsuccessful. However, because it knows nothing about the semantics of the arguments (such that C is an output and n should really match the array sizes), it is possible to abuse this function in ways that can cause Python to crash.
